data.title: Love it!!
data.text: Amazing, authentic French food! Fabulous cocktail and wine selection. The service was impeccable. The owners and chef are as warm and friendly as they are capable in the kitchen.

data.title: Confusing, horrible night, blamed everyone else for the problems.
data.text: OK, I waited a few weeks to write a review just to let things settle. My best friend was throwing a surprise party for his wife there. First off...they are listed as a restaurant & lounge, the Facebook page says it's a Bistro & Night Club but they also list authentic French cuisine?? Then I also see they have it listed as a Mediterranean restaurant? Since we were going to the party my wife and I thought we would get there early and have dinner before the party. We arrived at 8:00...the party wasn't until 9:30. We were greeted at the door and the hostess asked if we had reservations. I informed her that we didn't but as we were coming for the party we thought we would just have dinner also. She told us that they had a party of 12 dining so she wasn't sure if they could serve us dinner? The place was empty...besides the table of 12 in the corner. She said she would ask the owner? We were feeling rather awkward and as she went to check we agreed we would just go elsewhere. As she came back to us I was saying we would just go and the hostess said it was no problem as long as we were ok with eating at the bar? Well...ok...then as we were seated she mentions that we will need to order fast as the party of 12 was about to order as well? We should have just left right then. The Office does look way more like a TINY night club, looking very modern with LED lights and a few Paris type large photos on the walls...not really a "fine dining" look at all. I ordered the Caramelized truffle pork chop....in the menu description it said, pork chops, carrots, asparagus and truffle mashed potatoes. Wife ordered Cannelloni of Escargot. No salad was offered but for an upcharge they did offer a mushroom sauce...I ordered it on the side. Our food arrived rather quickly, portions were small, There was ONE chop on my plate...it said on the menu it was caramelized...looked to just be pan seared? A carrot and several green beans were set upon some asparagus. No truffle mashed potato to be found. Pork was good, not great...the mushroom sauce was very strong...glad I got it on the side. Everything had a vinaigrette drizzle over it...to make it fancy I guess? As we were eating we noticed it was very warm...I mentioned it to our server...who was also the hostess....and was also the bar tender. She said it was a very big place to cool and they were bringing in a few fans for the party? A man who I assume was the owner came out to the bar...he greeted us and asked how our dinner was....I mentioned the party and if they were ready for the 50 or so coming in just an hour or so, I also mentioned it was warm. He said it will be ok...they would be ready. We watched as he had a few cocktails of his own. Sooo, back to the meal...veggies were almost raw...pork chop was good...I was still hungry. Oh and the chop was $25. The party was a disaster as the a/c was OUT...they didn't have enough people behind the bar and wouldn't even serve anyone at first! Most arrived at around 9:15 and were told we weren't expected until 10 pm? We all ended up leaving...even took the DJ with us across the street...they had COLD a/c and bartenders!! The Office lost a ton of business that night...worst thing is they knew the a/c wasn't working properly several days before the event...as we heard from an employee. The owner even went on my friends event page on Facebook and blasted him for the party leaving! As if it was his fault!! I know there are about 50 folks who will never go there again....to the bistro, French, mediterran...tiny night club whatever they think they are.

data.title: Superb !!!!
data.text:
We thoroughly enjoyed our first dining experience at the The Office in Cape Coral.
We had a part of 5. Started with the Tuna Tartare, Ceviche and Foie Gras all being delicious.
As entrees we ordered, salmon, cog au vin, lobster ravioli. Next, we shared three different desserts, Chocolate Sublime,  FrenchCrepes and Creme Brûlée'. All dishes were attractively presented. The owners came to our table and asked about our experience. As we continued to talk, Marysol brought over a French Champagne and another tasting of wine.
What a great compliment to our experience. 
Yes, we will all return to The Office.

data.title: GOOD BUT NOT GREAT!
data.text: We thought we'd try this new restaurant and were surprised there was only one other couple at 7 pm for dinner. The decor was a little contemporary but fresh appearance. Jen, our server, was fun, attentive and provided excellent service. We were just a little disappointed at the selections. They had specials with wine/salad/entre/dessert and we tried the Salmon and Porkchop specials. You couldn't substitute and they both came with potatoes, which would have been nice to substitute. The meals were tasty but expensive. It would have been nice to see more people there. We probably won't revisit.

data.title: Best restaurant in Cape Coral
data.text:
Cape Coral has been waiting for this for a long time...
What a phantastic restaurant. Outstanding food & service.
Authentic french cuisine in a Miami South Beach designed restaurant with true European service. What a treat. The foie gras brioche is simply beyond your imagination. I could eat it every day.

data.title: Great food, service issues
data.text:
The food we ordered at dinner was sublime. The pork stack was something different and delectable, the risotto was outstanding. But they have some odd service policies, like not being able to order an app right away while you peruse the menu. The waitress spilled a very messy dish in one of our groups lap, and while we understand stuff happens, things like this usually mean an apology in the way of a drink or dessert or the offer of paying the cleaning bill--which was definitely required. Nada. We also had an unusually long wait given that the place was not at all crowded. 
And be aware of your beverage prices. They are pricey, for both wind and bar.
But----the food was truly excellent.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Glad to hear you enjoyed the food.  As for the service, we encourage people to order their entrees at the same time but definitely if you don't its fine but we need to let you know that French food is prepared differently and takes more time than traditional ways restaurants prepare food. with that in mind, we try to encourage people to order their entree so the Chef can start preparation.  I will address with my staff how to word such requests better than you may have experienced.  I hope you return and thank you for your review.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: So - So
data.text: The service was adequate but nothing special and the food, while good, was over priced.  There are better choices in the area.

data.title: Good Traditional French "Saveur"
data.text: An tastefully decorated upscale French restaurant in downtown Cape Coral that opened its doors last November. We just had to try it. For starters we had the soups of the day, Cream of Asparagus and Cream of Mushroom. Very tasty. For entrees, she ordered the 8 oz Filet Mignon, Foie gras sauce pommel new bridge. I had the Canard a l'orange. Both outstanding. For wine we had a bottle of Chateau Neuf du Pape. Surprisingly not from the "cellar". Florida room temperature is not what you expect from an authentic French restaurant. We have a wine cooler (refrigerator for wine) at our house that keeps our wine at the correct temperatures. I would hope by the time we visit again that the wine is served at cellar temperature. Other than that, yes expensive, but a nice place for that special occasion.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Thank-you so much for your review and we are thrilled you enjoyed it.  Yes , we will work on getting those wines chilled to the temperature they should be.  I hope you return in the near future and we appreciate your support.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Service and Food
data.text: Great food, there burgers are great and wine. They now have a full bar, and they have all types of drinks. There service was great and very friendly people.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Thank-you for your patronage and thank-you for your positive review.  We look forward to your future support and we will continue to try to strive to please our customers.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: 1st visit, great experience
data.text: The food was exquisite. lobster ravioli  and shrimp with risoto was wonderful,  We will definitely go back. Service was a tad slow,at first... but it was late and there was only one waiter. The food arrived hot and delicious, the owner came over and spoke with us and brought the chef out also. We love fine dining, and it lived up to a real "Paris" meal . The decor is very contemporary, only draw back is the "Coca Coke Cooler" is full view behind the bar.  Hopefully it will stay around, we would love a chance to try it a second time.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: We appreciate your patronage and your excellent review.  We look forward to serving you in the near future and we thank-you for your support.   Maybe I will decorate the cooler with some vines or something.  Thanks for bringing it to our attention.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Unfortunate
data.text:
We went to "The Office" to experience something in fine dining and left, well, disappointed to say the least.  I was underwhelmed with everything except the decor.  I've had the opportunity to eat at some very nice rated restaurants and was looking forward to experience something a cut above right here in Cape Coral.  
Reading the menu and components of each dish, it was hard for me to choose.  Everything sounded so exquisite and my taste buds were dancing with anticipation. My friend chose the duck and I chose the lamb.  We each started with an appetizer as well, which were not bad, but also not exceptional.  We waited quite a while before entrees were delivered.  My lamb was very fatty, a bit tough, and flavorless.  The potatoes were flavorless. The presentation was average (dated).  The table behind us complained about every dish they ordered.  It's unfortunate, because the concept and the decor have everything going for it.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: I am sorry for your disappointing experience at our restaurant and we have no excuse for your problems. I would like to say that we have replaced our Chef and our tweaking the menu and restructuring to make sure situations like this do not arise because we surely are here to strive for the best experience our customers can have. Once again, I am sorry and please try us again in the future.  We also have late nights with dancing on Thurs-Sat evenings and a full liquor bar is available.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Save your time & $$$$
data.text:
Haven't had this poor of an experience in a very long time.  This one spurred me to become a Trip Advisor member.
There eight of us five had the truffle pork chops - they were terrible - very thin and dried out with not a hint of truffle flavor anywhere to be found on the plate. Two of us had the lamb shanks with mashed potatoes. Not much flavor to the lamb shanks or the sauce on them. All of us sampled the mashed potatoes and none of us have had potatoes like those before,  none of us are really sure what they were? And finally the one in our group that suggested for us to try this place had the Octopus & Chorizo  she said it was ok. We spoke with the owner and his wife about our experience and were told that this is pretty much  how they prepare these dishes. Doubtful this place will be there long so not likely to many more people will have the disappointing experience that we paid for. This is one of, if not the most expensive places to dine in Cape Coral or Fort Myers.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, Owner at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: I am sorry for your experience and I talked to you while you were there and you ate the food we prepared which as I said while you were there, it is our recipes.  I am by no means saying it was perfect because you said it was not, but if you are not returning because of price and disliking the food, Trip Advisor's not meant to bash businesses, it was designed as a tool to help businesses improve or see praise from customers and give them the opportunity to better themselves.   We strive for the best experience for our customers and we could not satisfy you and for that I apologize.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Delicious and Sophisticated
data.text: We had our second meal here about a week ago, and happily the food and service held up to our first experience.  The Foie Gras Brioche appetizer is far and away our favorite on a menu of standouts. The pastry shell is flaky and delicious, with the interior of foie gras, egg and cream a savory and mouth-watering delight. Another "must-order" is the Octopus & Chorizo-- a delicious and well-prepared combination. The Duck L'Orange was outstanding, the Lobster Ravioli a savory yet light wonder, and my wife's Scallop Risotto so delicious I've vowed to order it next time we dine here.  The only mild criticism I have is that the Truffle Pork Chop which I had as my entree seemed slightly dry, despite a very well made sauce. Partially it was the fault of the cut, which seemed a little thin for the style of this dish. In addition to the excellent and expertly prepared food, the wine selection is interesting and reasonably priced.

data.title: Second Visit-Second Rate
data.text:
We returned to the Office as we had had a delightful meal our first visit. Our waitress was delightful but encouraged me to order the Lamb Shank Confit. Yes, the lamb was well cooked but one third fat. The vegetables were adequate but the mashed potatoes were lifeless. They appeared watery and were totally flavorless. The meal was $34. We shared a fois gras appetizer which turned out to be $28, the same price as our house wine. My husband's dish, a veal chop with a mushroom sauce was tough and flavorless.
We were there on a Friday night so I am sure that the chief chef was present. I am most disappointed with this second visit. I doubt I will ever return

data.title: Strange service, pretty good food
data.text:
We a started off on a peculiar note when our server introduced himself then asked for our first names as we ordered.  

The chef took great care with his ingredients and presentation.  Our soup of the day, cram of asparagus, was wonderful, full of flavor.  We picked a lovely white burgundy to go with our seafood main courses.  My friends liked the shrimp tempura and the grouper tapenade.  My shrimp and scallops were perfectly prepared but the accompanying risotto was like creamed rice with no flavor.  It was very disappointing.  

The service is not as competent as I would expect for the prices and the quality of food.  Our sever had not been trained about "serve from the left, clear from the right" and to serve beverages on the right.  Thus there was a lot of reaching across us at our table.  We had to pour our second glasses of wine ourselves, although there was ample time for the server to note our empty glasses.  He DID wait for a signal that we had all finished eating before he offered to clear the table, thank you.  I saw another server set a table by carrying three water glasses in one hand by the rims.  Would you want to drink from one of those glasses which had been handled on the inside and rim?

The meal took a while, I assume because the food was freshly prepared.  The Office does not have a liquor license, but the beer and wine selections were fine.

This is a fairly new restaurant, with a while to go to train staff to meet the level of the food.

The ambience is starkly modern.  If they get busy the concrete floor may make the place a little noisy.  More tablecloths may dampen the sounds of a full house.  We could talk easily with the place less than half full.

This is a longer than usual review for me, but I do want this chef to succeed.

data.title: Excellent evening
data.text: Was a little skeptical because of some previous reviews however we were simply overjoyed by both the service and food quality/quantity.  Arrived at 6:30 was warmly greeted promptly seated. Atmosphere is very nice, like any other Paris restaurant, very enjoyable evening.  Price is reasonable for the quality received.

owner_response.author: Marysol C, General Manager at The Office Restaurant & Lounge, responded to this review
owner_response.text: "Thanks a lot for your feedback.I'm glad you enjoyed the food and service.  We look forward to seeing you again soon !!!  Thanks again, Marysol Cros
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Excellent addition to the Cape
data.text: Visited for our first time the bight before Valentine's Day. Where was an event in the same area which made parking a little difficult and it was a bit loud. But the food soon made us forget. What an excellent meal. We started with the cheese plate, my favorite appetizer and/or dessert option! So glad they have this on the menu. The selection of cheeses was very good. I had a shrimp dish and my man had the special, lamb I think. Both meals excellent and so was the wine we selected. They do not have a full bar. The service was very good and the restaurant was clean and decorated beautiful. I would have liked for the restaurant manager to stop by our table, noticed him stopping and chatting with others but did not come to see us or ask about our meal.

data.title: A breath of fresh air
data.text:
This restaurant has been so many places in the past, and none of them have seemed to make it.  In the past, the décor has remained the same and just the menus have changed.....until now.  Immediately upon walking in the door, your first response is "WOW!"  It has been beautifully re-decorated in very stark blacks, whites and silvers.  The old dated carpet has ripped up and the concrete floor has been refinished in greys and browns.
The menu is rather small, and I would like to see more choices as they find their way.  The menu does not list any side dinner salads to have prior to your meal, and wen we asked about it our waiter said that the chef can easily put one together for us -- which he did.  We had to ask for the bread on the table, and were not given any butter or oil to go with it.  I think a nice assortment of a of few breads or lavash with an oil or tapenade would add a lot to the meal as a whole.  My husband had escargot for an appetizer.  It was prepared differently in that the escargot was not left whole but chopped with cheese and placed into stuffed  shells. There was a tomato based sauce that came with them that was fantastic. For dinner I had the lobster ravioli.  I must say there was quite a bit of lobster in each little pasta pocket and it came with appeared to be lobster bisque on the top.  For dessert, we both decided to split the crepes.  I would go there just for the crepes!  They were amazing!!  The crepes were light as air and filled with a delectable cream -- YUM!
We visited this restaurant when it was fairly new and I think they have a few little quirks to still work out, but if what we experienced was any indication of what it will be like after it matures a bit; I say "Welcome to Cape Coral and may you have many years of success!"

data.title: Amazing Food, Atmosphere and service!!!
data.text: My husband and I have eaten at the Office several times and I have to say the Chef who's name is Christian who I was able to meet is amazing. Looking at the website before I arrived, I knew it was what we were looking for.  Upscale decor, like something you would find in Miami , a nice price range of fie cuisine and a Chef from another country.  We had several dishes, the escargot, the lamb, the scallops, the ceviche and the brioche.  OMG!!! all amazing.  It was so nice not to be rushed and have food come out when you are in the middle of a course.  I also had the grapefruit wine because I was curious and it was really good, refreshing but not sweet, thank goodness. the server, Jenn reccomended it and said it was not sweet, and I was hesitant, but she was very correct.

user_location.name: La Fortuna de San Carlos, Costa Rica

data.title: No, I won't go back
data.text:
If you go to this restaurant's website, to look at their menu, the first thing that you may notice is that the font they use is small, and the color contrast with the background is poor - making it less than easy to read.

The next thing that you may notice is that the first food item listed is Foie Gras. This somewhat controversial food, with origins dating back more than four millennia, and which is illegal to produce in some states, happens to be one of my favorites. 

If you go back on the internet, and do a "Google" search for "wine to serve with Foie Gras", the first few thousand responses will all include, in one form or another, a wine called "Sauternes". This luscious, late-harvest, sweet white wine is produced in an appellation within the larger region of Bordeaux, France. There are a number of similar, but perhaps not comparable, wines which might also be listed, with sourcing as diverse as New York, California, Germany, central Europe and Australia, to name a few.

So, why would you open a new (they have actually been open more than 2 months) restaurant, under the pretense of being "gourmet quasi-French", and not have a Sauternes on the wine list, particularly when you are offering Foie Gras? Would you open a Japanese restaurant, but not offer Sake as a beverage, or and Italian restaurant that lacked Pinot Grigio or Chianti? They do not have a single wine, on a generally inferior list, that comes even close to being comparable. The single white wine they offer, that might have even a little residual sugar, is a German wine that comes from almost the absolute bottom of that country's quality scale. Taking it one step further, they don't offer even one dessert wine from any source!

To add insult to injury, this establishment has chosen to place itself at the top of heap of local restaurants that charge far too much for a "corkage fee". If you are not familiar with this term, it is a charge, paid by a customer, who elects to bring in his/her own wine to consume with a meal that they eat in the restaurant. The original presumption or justification for charging such a fee, is to cover the cost of equipment and utensils for the wine service - decanters, glassware, breakage and ware washing expenses. Over time, corkage has also become a profit source for restaurateurs who put together wine lists that are so mediocre that savvy customers are almost forced into bringing their own wine with them - which is entirely applicable to this case. Again, this establishment has not a single wine on their list that satisfies a centuries-old tradition of what to serve with Foie Gras, but they choose to charge as much (or more) as the cost of an entire dinner for the privilege of bringing in your own wine to enjoy. This is, quite simply, disrespectful to patrons.

I also feel sorry for the chef and those who toil in the kitchen, because being able to enjoy a fine, fairly priced wine with a well thought-out and prepared meal may almost certainly result in a dining experience that is better than the sum of the parts. Unfortunately, that's probably not going to happen here.

Yes, I know that "The Office" has received at least one positive professional review. But, that critique focused entirely on the food, and made no mention of the wine list or the potentially abusive treatment resulting from poor (make that terrible) management decisions. At the same time, if the "cost of goods" used to calculate their wine list pricing is justified or substantiated by the amount of their "corkage fee", then they are charging too much for their wine from the outset. Charging more than twice the price of what you would pay for a wine at retail is abusive and insulting, and people expecting respect should go elsewhere. Like me. Not surprisingly, there is no wine list to be found on their website.

If you think that I am being overly critical, allow me to provide a different perspective on the management. On a Sunday, just before noon (they open at 11 AM), without a single customer in the restaurant, they unequivocally refused to negotiate a more equitable corkage fee. It wasn't like they would be making a concession in front of a crowd, who might ask for the same or similar treatment in the future. They obviously preferred having no business, to some business that would have absolutely no negative impact on their food cost or very little on the bottom line.

A local newspaper occasionally publishes briefs about pending or current restaurant openings. With a few exceptions, such announcements often indicate that the new establishment will be occupying space previously used by a failed eatery. At some point, in the not too distant future, I expect to see such an announcement for this location.
